The dog-rose, of light-blushing hue,</br>Or painted in crimson-like vest,</br>Profuse in her bloom to the view,</br>The hedge-rows in splendour has drest.</br>The season of pleasure my lay</br>Extends in the country so bright;</br>The sweets of the new-tedded hay,</br>Each object of sound and of sight.

The trees we beheld in full dress,</br>Profusion of flowers around</br>The beauties of Nature confess,</br>In vivid sublimity crown'd,</br>On the banks of the river so clear,</br>Emerg'd from its wave are the flocks;</br>They mark the gay time of the year,</br>Depriv'd of their white fleecy locks.

When past is the soft copious shower,</br>The sweets of Arabia we find;</br>From the beds of the clover to flower,</br>And the bee-loving suckle resign'd.</br>More delicious the odours that rise</br>On the gales from the blue-bosom'd bean;</br>All Sweetness herself can comprize</br>Is pour'd in extend through the scene.

Whilst Summer, bright child of the Sun,</br>With mildness rekindles his fire;</br>And June, by his courtesy won,</br>Apparels in golden attire.</br>To her Prince Freedom offers the lay,</br>Whose sons the choice tribute support;</br>In duty rejoice at the day,</br>By far the most splendid at court.

Admit humble zeal to prevail,</br>From a Muse through unpolish'd to spring;</br>Bear hence, each Favonian gale,</br>The strain she devotes to her King.</br>No Laureat — what merit have I?</br>Pretension to fabricate praise?</br>Though humble and weak, yet too high</br>To flatter in time-serving lays.

My heart, by sincerity led,</br>The day of his birth shall revere,</br>That Peace may, her olive-branch spread,</br>Extend through each following year.</br>From my bosom warm wishes emane,</br>Ye Powers this blessing to send:</br>In the hearts of his subjects to reign</br>Till Time's latest period shall end.

Behold in what splendour appears,</br>In majesty boundless and wide,</br>The Sun through the dawn's pearly tears</br>Pouring down his ineffable tide.</br>Now beams in illustrious array,</br>And warms the aetherial gale,</br>Which nurtures the pride of the day,</br>From the hill to the green-herbag'd dale.

The bleatings of sheep from the hills,</br>The silence and peace of the grove,</br>The murmurs that rise from the rills,</br>And the reed from the shady alcove;</br>The zephyrs that pinion the hours,</br>The fragrance they widely diffuse,</br>The pasture, thick chequer'd with flowers,</br>Are themes that embellish my Muse.

How smooth and how tranquil the stream</br>Meanders the vallies along,</br>Its crystal improv'd by the beam</br>That wakens Aurora's first song!</br>The leaf by the gale unoppress'd,</br>The landscapes of Beauty and Grace,</br>Soft pleasures convey to the breast,</br>The smiles of the heart to the face.

Yet whither, my Muse, would you stray,</br>Evading this season of sweets?</br>Why turn from the purple-ey'd day,</br>From Pleasure's umbrageous retreats?</br>From the beech, ever vivid of shade,</br>The lime that elongates the lawn,</br>The oak, in dark foliage array'd,</br>Ah, why are thy visits withdrawn?

From the parks and the sports of the field,</br>Where plenty and happiness reign,</br>Where the smile of Benevolence yield</br>What blessings from Summer we gain;</br>Ah why, near yon sorrowful yew,</br>Of dark and disconsolate shade,</br>Must Elegy ever renew</br>Afflictions which never can fade?

Shall HONESTO, my father and friend,</br>Around whose respectable tomb</br>The Virtues all sorrowful bend,</br>In plaint recent dirges assume;</br>While Memory, Genius, and Worth</br>The red eye of Sorrow dilate;</br>Must pensively bow to the earth,</br>And weep his immutable fate?

Can he be forgot whom I lov'd,</br>Whose breast was so gentle and kind;</br>Of principles noble approv'd,</br>The Christian in precept and mind?</br>Can Time soothe the sigh of my breast?</br>The thunder that rolls on the hill</br>Shall sooner he sooth'd into rest,</br>Its lightnings no terrors instill.

Receive then my measure of woe,</br>Thou dearest and much-honour'd Shade:</br>If Virtue departed may know</br>Affection by relatives paid.</br>And yearly in Summer, bedeck'd</br>With splendour and wealth shall return;</br>My feelings fresh wreaths shall collect,</br>HONESTO, to garnish thy urn.</br>
